fields.description:
Our workflow has our engineers occasionally creating manual plan branches to run through one of our build plans. It would be awesome if it wasn't so cumbersome to create a manual plan branch as part of an engineer's testing.

We don't have the option to enable automatic plan branches as this build plan is very involved and takes over an hour to run. It would not be able to keep up with demand at all if it were run automatically.

One idea I have is smart commit hooks, like JIRA and Crucible use.

For example:

git commit -m "+bamboo run my_build_plan"

Or even a more-prominent button that makes it far easier to kick off a plan branch.
fields.summary: Easier UI for manually adding Plan Branches
Update Stock Image documentation
MySQL: Performance issues with orphan deletion after deleting deployment result

fields.description:
Setting "sudo /usr/bin/docker" as path for the docker capability doesn't seem to work.
To get docker builds working with bamboo (which runs as user bamboo in our setup) required to:
# Write a script /opt/run-docker.sh with the content 'sudo /usr/bin/docker "$@"'
# Add a sudoer entry: "bamboo ALL= NOPASSWD: /usr/bin/docker"
# Set the docker path in bamboo to "/opt/run-docker.sh"

It would be better if bamboo either offered a "run with sudo" checkbox for each capability or allow a full commandline instead of only a path to be configured as capabilitiy.

(Bamboo version 5.10.0 build 51017)
fields.summary: Sudo for server-capabilities

fields.description:
We have recently experienced some abnormal behavior that mimics the symptoms of BAM-13845, except that there is no nesting of SVN repositories going on.

Our situation is that for several plans, we have a structure like this:
Repositories:
* Default: SVN script repo (not used)
* SVN code repo (used)
* Git script repo (used)

The git script repo is our current one.  The checkout task in this order:
* SVN code repo to working directory
* Git script repo to scripts subdirectory

According to this, there should not be any nesting of SVN repositories.  The log, however, says:
{noformat}
simple	01-Mar-2016 09:22:38	Starting task 'Checkout Acme Repository' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs:task.vcs.checkout'
simple	01-Mar-2016 09:22:38	Running preRetrieveSourceCode task...
simple	01-Mar-2016 09:22:38	Build always requires a clean checkout
simple	01-Mar-2016 09:22:38	Cleaning build directory '/path/to/build/directory'
simple	01-Mar-2016 09:22:38	Build always requires a clean checkout
simple	01-Mar-2016 09:22:38	Cleaning build directory '/path/to/build/directory/scripts'
simple	01-Mar-2016 09:22:38	Updating source code to revision: 147
simple	01-Mar-2016 09:22:38	Existing workspace found at ''/path/to/build/directory''. updating...
error	01-Mar-2016 09:22:38	Update of ''/path/to/build/directory'' has been skipped for an unknown reason: [skip '/path/to/build/directory'], expected action: skip lock status: lock_inapplicable
simple	01-Mar-2016 09:22:39	Updated source code to revision: 147
simple	01-Mar-2016 09:22:39	Running postRetrieveSourceCode task...
simple	01-Mar-2016 09:22:39	Updating source code to revision: deadbeefcafe-blahblahblah
simple	01-Mar-2016 09:22:39	Creating local git repository in '/path/to/build/directory/scripts/.git'.
{noformat}

There isn't any SVN repo in the build directory--nothing hidden, no .svn, et cetera.  The *only* way to make this work is to force the repo to check out into a subdirectory of the working directory.  While this is acceptable for this particular build, it does not make sense for us that an SVN repository cannot check out into a clean directory.
fields.summary: Bamboo not checking out SVN files

fields.description:
In the Visual Studio Task configuration, the Platform dropdown list shows x86, ia64, etc.
The "Any CPU" option is missing.
fields.summary: Add "Any CPU" to Platform in Visual Studio Task

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

For XSS protection, certain "dangerous" characters are not allowed for input in many fields in Bamboo, including for requirements. One such character is the ampersand (&), which can be used for logical AND expressions (such as "a && b" for "a AND b"). At the moment, because XSS protection applies to these fields too, these characters cannot be used in requirements even though they are necessary for the requirements to be processed correctly.

h3. Suggested Solution
 
A Bamboo administrator should have a way to override or disable the XSS protection (either as a global option or on a more granular level).

h3. Workaround

There is no workaround available
fields.summary: As an administrator I want to be able to configure whether XSS protection should apply to requirements or not

fields.summary: Stopping a running build fails from build page

fields.description:
It looks like https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-15346


h3. Reproducing issue:
# create a new Project (i.e.: Support), Plan (i.e.: MyPlan)
# add an "{{Script}}" task
{code}
# creates a new file
touch executable.jar

# list files
ls -l

# change its permission
chmod 755 executable.jar

# list files
ls -l
{code}
As a result you would have something like:
{noformat}
12-Dec-2014 14:08:52	total 0
12-Dec-2014 14:08:52	-rw-r--r--  1 root  root  0 Dec 12 14:08 executable.jar
12-Dec-2014 14:08:52	total 0
12-Dec-2014 14:08:52	-rwxr-xr-x  1 root  root  0 Dec 12 14:08 executable.jar
{noformat}
# create an Artifact definition as per following:
{noformat}
Name: myArtifact
Location:
Copy pattern: executable.jar
[x] Shared
{noformat}
# go to "{{<bamboo-home>/artifacts}}" and run the following:
{code}
ls -l SUP-MYPLAN/shared/build-00001/myArtifact/executable.jar
{code}
As a result you would have something like:
{noformat}
-rw-r--r--  1 root  root  0 Dec 12 14:08 SUP-MYPLAN/shared/build-00001/myArtifact/executable.jar
{noformat}

h3. Workaround
- Write a script job that will re-set the correct permissions
- Tar everything up before creating the artifacts and then pass around a tarball rather than just pure artifacts.
fields.summary: Artifact permissions are not preserved regression

fields.description:
Summary
=======
Given a plan expiration:

{code}
BuildExpiryBeanImpl Using plan defined expiry config for THE-PLN: BuildExpiryConfig[enabled=true,buildsToKeep=0,period=8 days,maxIgnoredLogSize=0,cronExpression=<null>,expiryTypes=[],labelsToKeep=[]]
{code}

where nothing is listed in the expiryTypes array,  will cause Bamboo to "loop" through the plan and not move on to expire others. 

Diagnostics
=========
Setting com.atlassian.bamboo.build.expiry = DEBUG should show repeated calls to the same plan:

{code}
[BuildExpiryBeanImpl] Found 500 build(s) to expire for THE-PLN
{code}

Workaround
=========
Manually re-save the plan expiration, overriding any defaults and ensuring that something is selected for expiration. This should update the metadata in the DB and allow the pan to be expired.
fields.summary: Empty expiryTypes prevents expiration of additional plans

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Bamboo can't create a JIRA issue if the project does not have the _description_ field on any screen
h3. Environment
* Bamboo 5.9.7
* JIRA 7

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create application links between Bamboo and JIRA
# Remove the description field from all screen on JIRA project
# Go to Bamboo build results, Actions > Create JIRA issue
# Enter the details, description can be left blank
# Create

h3. Expected Results
Issue should be created as there is no description content
h3. Actual Results
UI throws this error:
{noformat:borderStyle=dashed}
Field 'description' cannot be set. It is not on the appropriate screen, or unknown.
{noformat}

Logs throw:
{noformat:borderStyle=dashed}
2016-02-26 17:23:24,039 WARN [http-bio-8085-exec-21] [JiraRestServiceImpl] Failed to execute application link request. Server: http://localhost:8080/jira Method: POST Url: rest/api/latest/issue
Response: 400 Bad Request
Errors: Errors[errorMessages=[],errors={description=Field 'description' cannot be set. It is not on the appropriate screen, or unknown.}]
{noformat}
fields.summary: Can't create a JIRA issue that has no description field

fields.description:
h4. Summary
Proper caching of submodules. Right now Bamboo does not cache submodules and results in a ton of traffic across the network during builds, especially for larger submodule repos.
fields.summary: Proper submodule caching

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When checking out submodules Bamboo receives a _Host key verification failed_ error like below
{code}
Submodule 'Bools/BoolCommon' (ssh://de35af7f-7f53-4023-cbe3-93fe9415b6a3@127.0.0.1:55298/bools/bool-common.git) registered for path 'Bools/BoolCommon'
Cloning into 'Applications/PATT/Tests/Data'...
Host key verification failed.
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

Please make sure you have the correct access rights
and the repository exists.
{code}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Configure Bitbucket Server repository with submodules
# Add repository to *Linked Repositories* in Bamboo
# Configure Bamboo plan to checkout repository

h3. Expected Results
Bamboo checks out submodules without issue

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the build log file:
{noformat}
Host key verification failed.
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

Please make sure you have the correct access rights
and the repository exists.
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
* Git submodule command accesses local ssh proxy checking fingerprint of server.
* Bamboo is using generated ssh key for main repository, not the one for the submodule

h3.Workaround
# Add to ~/.ssh/config two lines to ignore fingerprint when connecting to localhost. 
{code}
Host localhost
	StrictHostKeyChecking no

Host 127.0.0.1
	StrictHostKeyChecking no
{code}
(i) If the modification above is successful, the proxy will be able to connect to Bitbucket Server (fka Stash) to subsequently run the submodule command.
OR
# Run Git Clone command for the submodule repository manually to verify the host key

h4. Note
When you use submodule with global path, git will bypass the on-demand, intermediary, locally created SSH proxy that it normally uses to connect to the repo, and connect to it directly. This requires that the SSH key must be available at the OS level. However, when your submodule uses a relative path, git will interface with it via the proxy similarly to how it connects to the parent repository. For this reason, it might be necessary to duplicate and copy the auto-generated, public SSH access key of the parent repository to the Access Keys of each related submodule repo.

Reference: [Identify which project or repository a SSH key is associated with|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServerKB/Identify+which+project+or+repository+a+SSH+key+is+associated+with]
fields.summary: Host key verification failed when retrieving submodule

fields.description:
Currently to link a JIRA issue in Bamboo a developer has to put the issue in a commit message.  

We are using BitBucket as our repository and to link issues there you can put the Issue in the Branch name (which is done automatically if you use JIRA to open the branch).  I would like for Bamboo to be able to read that linked issue and import that against the build/deploy.
fields.summary: JIRA Issue Linking through BitBucket

fields.description: When deploying to my production environment and selecting the option "Promote existing release to this environment", all branches are shown. I would like to filter out (not even allow the user to mistakenly select) branches that are inappropriate to deploy to the given environment. For example, prevent a development release from being selected to deploy to production. Is this possible? Or, maybe this feature can be added?
fields.summary: Deployment Environment Plan Branch/Release filtering

fields.description:
When deploying to an environment manually, I can select:
Promote existing release to this environment...and pick the "Release" I want to deploy.

When setting up an environment trigger schedule, you can only pick a "Plan Branch". It would be great if we could select a "Release" for our scheduled deployment.
fields.summary: Deployment Environment Trigger Schedule with Release Option

fields.description:
Build plan with repositories associated with it:
||Repository||Source Code Checkout||Checkout Directory||
|repo.git|repo_working_directory| |
|repoA.git|repo_working_directory-A|A|
|repoB.git|repo_working_directory-B|B|
|repoC.git|repo_working_directory-C|C|

Running build plan:
* (/) source code checkout from 'repo_working_directory'
* (/) source code checkout from 'repo_working_directory-A'
* (/) source code checkout from 'repo_working_directory-B'
* (x) source code checkout from 'repo_working_directory-C'
{code}
simple	25-Feb-2016 10:17:34	Receiving objects:   0% (123/456789), 123.45 MiB | 12.34 MiB/s   
simple	25-Feb-2016 10:17:34	fatal: The remote end hung up unexpectedly
simple	25-Feb-2016 10:17:34	fatal: early EOF
simple	25-Feb-2016 10:17:34	fatal: index-pack failed
simple	25-Feb-2016 10:17:34	Warning: failed to checkout source code to directory '<bamboo-home>/xml-data/build-dir/PROJ-PLAN-JOB1', trying to recover...
simple	25-Feb-2016 10:17:34	Cleaned source directory '<bamboo-home>/xml-data/build-dir/PROJ-PLAN-JOB1'...
{code}

Cleanup seems to be running *only* against '{{Build Working Directory}}' and not taking into consideration '{{Checkout Directory}}' when set up. Consequently, the only source code found in the Build Working Directory is from '{{repo_working_directory-C}}' as retries the source code checkout only from the failure one.

By changing the scenario to the following, Bamboo would clean up the '{{Build Working Directory}}' and '{{A, B and C}}' would be deleted.
* (/) source code checkout from 'repo_working_directory-A'
* (/) source code checkout from 'repo_working_directory-B'
* (/) source code checkout from 'repo_working_directory-C'
* (x) source code checkout from 'repo_working_directory'
In this case, Bamboo should keep track of previous '{{Source Code Checkout}}' tasks configuration and:
# re-run them in case of failure OR;
# delete *only* the content from failure checkout

Sample clean up Build Working Directory
{code}
rethrowOrRemoveDirectory(e, buildLogger, workspaceDir, "repository.git.messages.rsRecover.failedToFetchWorkingDir");
...
BambooPathUtils.deleteQuietly(directory.toPath());
{code}
fields.summary: Source Code Checkout cleanup 'Build Working Directory' instead of 'Checkout Directory'

fields.description: Currently the private keys and passphrases are only Base64 encoded when stored in the database, they're not encrypted at all. It would be nice if we could better protect this data in upcoming releases. Base64 is just encoding and can be reversed, so it's not secure. If we could encrypt this data and store an encrypted version of them, it would be great, as this can be a major security concern for users.
fields.summary: Encrypt private key and passphrase

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When adding a *Linked repository* of the following Repository host types under "Advanced options > Web repository the option "Stash (legacy)" is visible but Stash never supported these types:

- CVS
- Subversion
- Perforce
- Mercurial

h3. Steps to Reproduce -- one example
# Administration > Linked repositories
# Select the button to "Add repository"
# Select "Mercurial" from the drop-down *Repository host*
# Select *Advanced options" to expand the selection.
# Under *Web Repository* select "Stash (legacy)".

h3. Expected Results
Only these options should be available under *Web Repository*:
- None
- FishEye
- Mercurial Hg serve Web Repository
- Bitbucket Web Repository

h3. Actual Results
These options are available under *Web Repository*:
- None
- FishEye
- Stash (legacy)
- Mercurial Hg serve Web Repository
- Bitbucket Web Repository

h3.Workaround
Don't select this option.
fields.summary: Stash (legacy) shouldn't be an option under Web Repository for several Repository host types

fields.description:
Currently the Pre-Post Build Command Runner plugin will function only when the build is able to start. In Bamboo when customers are using the automatic merging feature Bamboo preforms the merge before starting the build of course. If Bamboo fails to start the build due to a merge conflict the Pre-Post Build Command does not fire. 

The expectation is that the command will fire without issues.
fields.summary: Pre-Post Build Command Runner plugin should still trigger if build fails on merge

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When retrieving information through REST API using the _/result_ URI (and its childs _/result/PROJECTKEY_, _result/PROJECTKEY-PLANKEY_) no information from builds that were manually stopped are returned, only the ones that succeeded or failed are.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Start a build and let it complete (succeeding or failing)
# Start another build and manually stop it
# cURL the URI to get the info
curl -u user http://<bamboo-url>/<bamboo-context-path>/rest/api/latest/result

h3. Expected Results
[Bamboo REST Resources|https://developer.atlassian.com/bamboodev/rest-apis/bamboo-rest-resources] doc states it "Lists the latest builds for all plans on the Bamboo server" so it should list the latest build that was manually stopped (since its build number is higher than the previous one that completed).
h3. Actual Results
The previous build is listed (the one that completed, failing or succeeding) even though its build number is lower than the one that was manually stopped

h3.Workaround
You can use the _/result/PROJECTKEY-PLANKEY/BUILDNUMBER_ URI to return information of the specific builds if you know the build number of the build that was manually stopped.
fields.summary: REST API /result URI doesn't return info from manually stopped builds

fields.description:
We're having a lot of problems with bamboo deciding our git cache is corrupt, and redownloding it. (It's rather large, approx. 2Gb, which I know is not recommended but I have to live with it for now).

What I think is happening is that while one local agent is checking out source, another agent does a "fetch" and so changes the contents of the repository, meaning the first agent fails. The first agent then decides the cache is corrupt and re-downloads it.

From poking around and seeing what commands bamboo is sending to git, it appears to be initialised as a standard repository - i.e. the command "git init" rather than "git init --bare" - I wonder if this could be the cause? 

At the moment most of our agents spend longer updating source to latest than they do building.
fields.summary: Git Cache getting corrupted regularly

fields.description:
h4. Problem

In product help (?) is grammatically incorrect on the Administration > Linked Repositories page when trying to add a Bitbucket Server / Stash repo:

!2016-02-23_1540.png|thumbnail!

h4. Expected

{quote}
SSH public key storage
If you have administrative permissions to the selected repository, Bamboo stores the new public key in Bitbucket Server as *an* access key. This is the recommended approach to avoid issues when user permissions change.
If you don't have administrative permissions to the selected repository, Bamboo stores the new public key in in Bitbucket Server as *a* user profile key. Storing keys in user profiles is more likely to lead to issues when user permissions change.
For more information, see Bitbucket Server.{quote}

h4. Actual
{quote}SSH public key storage
If you have administrative permissions to the selected repository, Bamboo stores the new public key in Bitbucket Server as one the access keys. This is the recommended approach to avoid issues when user permissions change.
If you don't have administrative permissions to the selected repository, Bamboo stores the new public key in in Bitbucket Server as one the user profile keys. Storing keys in user profiles is more likely to lead to issues when user permissions change.
For more information, see Bitbucket Server.{quote}
fields.summary: Typo in in-product help on Add Repo page (Bitbucket Server / Stash)

fields.description:
We're down-rev at 5.7.2 build 5716 - 02 Dec 14, so please pardon this if you've incorporated something along these lines.

*Background:*  I have a plan that should be runnable on 15 injectors; however it's proven flakey on 1 rascally node.   Accordingly, I've been pleased to use your regexp-capable requirements field to exclude #8.  ( {{app-ci-1?\[^8]$}} )

*Feature Request:*   I've found nowhere to annotate why this configuration is so, so I've made my explanation in the *Job Description* field.   I know you can't be adding "comment" fields to every tab of every stage, task & overall plan definition, but I ask you to consider providing perhaps 1 comment field for, say, each stage/task and/or plan definition
fields.summary: provide 1 comment field for each stage/task and/or plan definition

fields.description:
Currently, at least in [Variables for deployment|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/variables-for-deployment-environments-342754180.html] plans, it seems that every time a variable contains "PASSWORD" in its name its value is masked with {{********}}. Also, when editing such variables their values are flushed out.

I understand the idea but it becomes a real pain when we don't want that behavior. For example, I have a variable named "ENCRYPT_PASSWORD_COMMAND" which is a command that depends on the environment I'm deploying on. And since it contains "PASSWORD", the command is masked and cannot be altered easily unless the person knows it, copies it back and makes the adjustment...

So, I propose that such a mechanism be configurable with a check-box on the side. Trying to guess if a variable should be obfuscated or not should not prevent users from configuring their plans the way they like/need. That should remain a helper and not become a difficulty.
fields.summary: Allow masking of build variables to be configurable

fields.description:
When creating Plan Repository or Linked Repository, it would be better to have an option to store the SSH key into Bitbucket Server Repository Access Key or User Account.

In the latest Bamboo version, the SSH key is stored in Bitbucket Server Repository Access Key if the user have the permission to edit the Repository setting. If the user does not have the permission, then the SSH key will be stored in the User account.

Due to Bitbucket Server Branch Permission, the SSH key stored in Bitbucket Server Repository Access Key does not work with Bamboo Branch Updater or Gatekeeper.

It would be great if there is an option to select storing SSH key in User account when creating Repository in Bamboo.

h4.Workaround
# Create a user in Bitbucket Server without the Admin permission to the Repository
# Create a user with the same username in Bamboo with Admin Permission
# Configure this user to have Branch Permission in Bitbucket Server
# Login with the new user in Bamboo to delete and recreate the Repository
If it is a Linked Repository, will need to re-add the repository into Plan Configuration
# Stop Bamboo
# Backup Bamboo database for rollback purposes
# Run the following SQL in Bamboo database
{code:sql}
SELECT * FROM vcs_location WHERE NAME='<display-name-in-step-4>' ORDER BY VCS_LOCATION_ID DESC LIMIT 1;
{code}
The SSH key stored in column XML_DEFINITION_DATA looks like the following example:
{noformat}
      <key>
        <private>xxx...</private>
        <public>ssh-rsa yyy... http://localhost:8085</public>
        <isRepositoryStoredKey>false</isRepositoryStoredKey>
      </key>
{noformat}
This is the SSH key generated by Bamboo to be stored in Bitbucket Server User account in step 4
The SSH key used by Branch Plan might still be the old SSH key
# Run the following SQL query to search for old repository setting
{code:sql}
SELECT * FROM vcs_location WHERE NAME='<old-display-name>';
{code}
# Update all the result to have the same SSH key
# Restart Bamboo
fields.summary: Ability to choose User Account or Repository Access Key to store the SSH key

fields.description:
h4. Summary

The Windows service installation script sets heap values that are different than those defined when running from the command-line (set using {{setenv.bat}}).

h4. Expected result

Heap is defined with these values:

set JVM_MINIMUM_MEMORY=256m
set JVM_MAXIMUM_MEMORY=768m{noformat}


h4. Actual result

{{service.bat}}
{noformat}
"%EXECUTABLE%" //IS//%SERVICE_NAME% ^

    --LogPath "%CATALINA_BASE%\logs" ^
    --StdOutput auto ^
    --StdError auto ^

    --StartMode jvm ^
    --StopMode jvm ^

fields.description:
The CodeDeploy plugin does not support IAM Role Based Temporary Credentials.  This is problematic, as it requires us to grant virtually full access to all IAM accounts that need CodeDeploy permissions.  We need to limit access to only those applications/buckets that specific DevOps teams need access to.

Basically the CodeDeploy plugin does not work properly if AWS IAM user is limited to specific AWS resources by via an IAM policie.  When this restricted configuration is used, the CodeDeploy plugin fails to list authorized “Amazon S3 bucket”s and “CodeDeploy application”s

Using:
- Bamboo Version 5.10.1.1
- Bamboo AWS CodeDeploy Plugin - 1.0.7
- Java 1.8.0_71
- App Server Apache Tomcat/8.0.24


Example AWS IAM Resources and Policy configuration:

*AWS Resources with full access*
"arn:aws:codedeploy:::*",
"arn:aws:s3:::*",

*AWS Resources with limited access*
"arn:aws:codedeploy:::application01"
"arn:aws:codedeploy:::application02"
"arn:aws:s3:::bucket01/*"
"arn:aws:s3:::bucket02/*"

In the following JSON if we replace the restricted resources "arn:aws:codedeploy:::application01" and "arn:aws:codedeploy:::application02" with the unrestricted "arn:aws:codedeploy:::*",
and if we replace the restricted resources "arn:aws:s3:::bucket01/" and "arn:aws:s3:::bucket02/" with the unrestricted "arn:aws:s3:::*" the policy configuration works.

{noformat}
{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Action": [
                "autoscaling:*",
                "codedeploy:*",
                "ec2:*",
                "s3:*",
                "elasticloadbalancing:*",
                "iam:AddRoleToInstanceProfile",
                "iam:CreateInstanceProfile",
                "iam:CreateRole",
                "iam:DeleteInstanceProfile",
                "iam:DeleteRole",
                "iam:DeleteRolePolicy",
                "iam:GetInstanceProfile",
                "iam:GetRole",
                "iam:GetRolePolicy",
                "iam:ListInstanceProfilesForRole",
                "iam:ListRolePolicies",
                "iam:ListRoles",
                "iam:PassRole",
                "iam:PutRolePolicy",
                "iam:RemoveRoleFromInstanceProfile",
                "tag:GetTags",
                "tag:GetResources"
            ],
            "Resource": [
                "arn:aws:autoscaling:::*",
                "arn:aws:codedeploy:::application01",
                "arn:aws:codedeploy:::application02",
                "arn:aws:ec2:::*",
                "arn:aws:s3:::bucket01/*",
                "arn:aws:s3:::bucket02/*",
                "arn:aws:elasticloadbalancing:::*",
                "arn:aws:iam:::*",
                "arn:aws:tag:::*"
            ]
        }
    ]
}
{noformat}



Note the JSON has some of the ARN details removed for security reasons.
fields.summary: CodeDeploy plugin does not support IAM Role Based Temporary Credentials

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Allowing Bamboo to terminate any disconnected instance is a risk for customers that haven't created a separate EC2 account for Bamboo. It allows regular Bamboo Administrators to terminate potentially production EC2 instances.

h3. Suggested Solution

Either put terminate disconnected instances behind a permission or setting or remove it altogether.
 
h3. Workaround

Ensure only trusted users have Bamboo Administrator permission.
fields.summary: Remove bamboo capacity to terminate disconnected instances

fields.description: It would be nice for automation/security purposes to be able to change the deployment private key from the API so it's not only updated from within the UI.
fields.summary: REST API call to update deployment private key

fields.description:
Add the option to deploy a deployment project manually using just one-click instead of four-clicks. Or if possible, just shorten the process to 1 or 2 clicks instead of 4. 

If I want to manually deploy a deployment, I have to do the following steps:
1. Click "Deploy" from the very top menu and select "All Deployment Projects", 
2. Click "Deploy" on the Deployment Project
3. Select "Create new release from build result".
4. Then click "Start deployment" button.

We're trying to grant more people to do run deployment project, but we prefer a one click button, as oppose to three or four clicks, in order to avoid people from clicking the wrong button and mess things up, especially the second option where you have to first select "Create new release from build result" and don't do the default, which is "Promote existing release to this environment" (we don’t want the default, we pretty much always want to deploy the next/new build).

We just want to make it reeaally simple, so people don't have to think about too much and just click one button to deploy manual deployment, that way, people have less chances of messing things up in a deployment.  Thanks.
fields.summary: One click to deploy a deployment project
Bamboo makes git to store plaintext password on the build server

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
On AWS, users want to be able to specify a custom home directory for Bamboo Elastic Agents

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow elastic agents to specify a custom home directory similar to remote agents

h3. Workaround
To work around this you must symlink the default elastic agent bamboo home directory to another location 
E.g.
{code}
mklink /D C:\Users\Bamboo\bamboo-agent-home D:\bamboo
{code}
fields.summary: Allow elastic agents to set custom home directory location

fields.description:
I had started this dialog at https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/36602948/answers/37028709

In short, Bamboo does not seem to checkout source code for a repository the same way I do, via `git clone` and there may even be a cache of that repository sitting around on the bamboo Linux agent that is outdated, in regards to at least the list of branches.

Example, create a bamboo build plan such that it does not remove the workspace after the job is done.
Then `cd` to that workspace and run:
git branch -r | wc -l
to get the count of branches.
then run
git fetch --prune
which would delete locally, any branches that no longer exist on the remote stash repository.
then run
git branch -r | wc -l
to see if the number of branches has changed.

Now, as a human being, checkout a workspace on the same machine (or other machine) using the `git clone` syntax,
then run 
git fetch --prune
git branch -r | wc -l

Are the number of branches in the 2 scenarios, similar or very different?
fields.summary: Provide checkbox to have source code checked out with git clone and no shortcuts, and a way to remove cache

fields.description:
Currently the *bamboo-capabilities.properties* file should be placed inside the {{<bamboo-agent-home>/bin}} folder according to the [Configuring remote agent capabilities using bamboo-capabilities.properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+remote+agent+capabilities+using+bamboo-capabilities.properties] OR should be located in the same directory as the *bamboo-agent-.jar* file when *not* using the wrapper, according to the [Legacy remote agent installation guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Legacy+remote+agent+installation+guide].

It would be nice to have the file be read from $BAMBOO_HOME or whatever -Dbamboo.home is set to. Optionally providing a way to override that would be useful as well, via some {{-Dbamboo.capabilities=/path/to/bamboo-capabilities.properties}}.
fields.summary: Load the bamboo-capabilities.properties file from $BAMBOO_HOME or whatever -Dbamboo.home is set to.

fields.description: We are wanting to be able to retrieve permissions for build plans via the REST API. We want this so we can automate auditing our plan setup. Too often a person creates a plan and forgets to set permissions beyond themselves or they don't set them properly.
fields.summary: Retrieve Permissions for Build Plans via REST API

fields.description:
*Actual Behavior*
Currently Bamboo does not have an ability to allocate some Bamboo instances to be on-demand and others to be spot instances.

Having a fall-back set up so that once spot request fails, it will falls back to on-demand after a minute. This will cause a long delay for the developers as it will takes up to 10 minutes for bamboo to be available for a build and plus the delay from the spot requests itself.

*Requested Behaviour*
Bamboo Cloud provides an ability so that we can run a set number of instances to be on-demand the rest to be spot instances. This is to ensure that there are always some (on-demand) instances available for immediate builds.

For example, from Administration page on Bamboo Cloud, we can set certain number of instances to be on-demand, the rest to be spot instances.
fields.summary: Ability to allocate some Bamboo instances to be on-demand and others to be spot instances

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently the Support Tools Plugin (STP) only collects the {{atlassian-bamboo.log}} file from the {{<BambooHome>/logs}} directory. When log file rotation is configured, those rotated log files (e.g. {{atlassian-bamboo.log.1}}, {{atlassian-bamboo.log.2}} are not included in the support zip.

h3. Suggested Solution
 
The STP should collect all files in {{<BambooHome>/logs}}

h3. Workaround

Manually collect the files and send them to support
fields.summary: Bamboo STP plugin should collect all log files

fields.description:
Since the release of 5.10/5.10.1 there were changes to the API meaning that calls used by add-ons that deal with versioning would need to call setChangeSetId() as a enforced requirement. Add-ons that dont do this may break. 

The fix for this is to ensure that it is raised in the documentation as a visible change so developers will be aware.
fields.summary: Document behavioural change for setChangeSetId

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bamboo reuse of artifact copy patterns in deployment may produce undesired results.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# In a build plan define 3 different jobs.
# For each job define an artifact with the same copy pattern: file-*.txt
# Mark each artifact definition as shared.
# Each job produces one file: file-x86.txt, file-amd64.txt and file-sparc.txt respectively.
# Configure a deployment project to link to the plan mentioned above
# In the deployment project define 3 separate SCP tasks, one for each artifact produced by the build.
# Set as the remote path in each task something like: deployment-x86/file-x86.txt, deployment-amd64/file-amd64.txt, and deployment-sparc/file-sparc.txt respectively.
# Run the build plan
# Run the deployment project.

h3. Expected Results

The file deployment-x86/file-x86.txt file has the contents of the file-x86.txt produced by the build plan.
The file deployment-amd64/file-amd64.txt file has the contents of the file-amd64.txt produced by the build plan.
The file deployment-sparc/file-sparc.txt file has the contents of the file-sparc.txt produced by the build plan.

h3. Actual Results

The file deployment-x86/file-x86.txt file has the contents of file-sparc.txt produced by the build plan.
The file deployment-amd64/file-amd64.txt file has the contents of file-sparc.txt produced by the build plan.
The file deployment-sparc/file-sparc.txt file has the contents of the file-sparc.txt produced by the build plan.
 
h3. Notes

In the example above Bamboo copies 3 times to the destination (in general the number of  matches for the copy pattern) and overwrites the destination file but keeps the name. In the example above all destination files have the same contents (of file-sparc.txt) with different names. The contents is determined by the last name in the copy pattern match (in the example above file-sparc.txt).

h3.Workaround

Use more specific copy patterns when defining the artifacts. For example for the artifact file-x86.txt use a copy pattern of file-x86.txt and so on.
fields.summary: Bamboo reuse of artifact copy patterns in deployment may produce undesired results

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When creating branches via the REST API, "Clean up branch automatically" is not enabled in the plan's Branch Details configuration. There is no other endpoint available to do this, so this option must be enabled by hand

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow this option to be specified as an additional parameter in the API call, e.g.:{code}http://localhost:8085/rest/api/latest/plan/PROJ-PLAN/branch/BranchName?vcsBranch="/refs/heads/myBranch&cleanup=true{code}
Alternatively, Change the defaults for API created branches to enable "Clean up branch automatically" by default

h3. Workaround
None
fields.summary: Allow "Clean Branch Plan Automatically" when creating branches via REST API

fields.description:
When using a linked repository with repository host Git, selecting the "None" type is ignored if there is information in the Username field. To reproduce:

1. Set up a linked repository with Repository Host Git
2. Select Authentication Type "Username/password" and enter information into fields
3. Select Authentication Type "None"

*Results*: Repository tries to use entered Username/password to connect to Git repository
*Expected*: Repository is accessed anonymously as specified in documentation for "None" Authentication Type

*Work Around*: Select Authentication Type "Username/password" and manually clear out username and password fields. Select Authentication Type "None" again.
fields.summary: Git Linked Repository Authentication Type "None" Ignored

fields.description:
When a Bitbucket Server-type linked repository in created in Bamboo, authentication is handled by using the credentials of the user who created the linked repository. This is great because it simplifies the authentication process, but also causes the repository to break if the user ever leaves the company or loses access to the repository in Bitbucket Server, then the repository breaks for everyone on Bamboo's side. Fixing this is easy - just re-save the repository (thus using your credentials for authentication). However, diagnosing this problem can be tricky, especially if you aren't aware of how authentication is handled in the first place. 

To help fix authentication issues when they arise, two things would be good:
# Display who's credentials are being used whenever a repository is mentioned in Bamboo (i.e. Linked Repositories, Plan Configuration, Branch Configuration)
# Add a button that tests these credentials.
fields.summary: In the UI, expose the account used for authenticating to Bitbucker Server-type repositories and provide a button to test the connection

fields.description: When build concurrency is enabled a subfolder in the working directory is created for each of the agents as Bamboo recognizes them. In instances where the builds are sharing an incremented file that each build actions on different copies are made for different agents as a result of the subfolder creation. This can cause discrepancies between the files and it would be great if there was a shared artifact directory for all of these to be pulled from to help mitigate this use case.
fields.summary: Build concurrency not maintaining artifact integrity

Build artifacts are shared even when a build ultimately fails. In many cases this means the artifacts produced will be unusable anyway, and some customers would like to prevent artifacts being shared for failed builds.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add configuration option to only share artifact if build passes

h3. Workaround
n/a

fields.description:
According to the documentation at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO055/Elastic+Bamboo+Security#ElasticBambooSecurity-VPCs Bamboo instances can be attached to EC2 VPCs.

Unfortunately the documentation does not tell you how to do this, not does it link to documentation to tell you how to do this, and Bamboo itself does not follow the principal of least surprise with respect to this configuration.

Please update the docs to clearly indicate how to add an EC2 VPC to Bamboo.

NOTE: FOR THE AVOIDANCE OF DOUBT - this ticket covers documentation for Bamboo ONLY, the creation of EC2 VPCs is obviously documented by Amazon, the missing documentation referred to by this bug refers to what changes you need to make to Bamboo to switch on an EC2 VPC created earlier.
fields.summary: Bamboo documentation: EC2 VPC is undocumented

fields.description:
It would be nice to have wallboards and filtering for deployment plans, in the same way there currently are for build plans.
We have a significant number of deployment plans. The All Deployments page is very slow to load. It would be nice to be able to display only the relevant subset of plans instead of displaying all plans. 
For example, if there are several related systems there could be a wallboard showing the deployment plans for only those systems. A release manager could have a wallboard which shows only production deployment environments and no development environments.
fields.summary: Wallboard and/or filters for deployment plans

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
At the start of every build, the build log prints out a list of all Git branches and tags in the repository when creating the local, cached copy on the agent. Repositories containing a high number of branches and tags end up with Bamboo build logs full of of these log entries. This inflates the size of the log and makes parsing it for actual relevant information difficult.

{noformat}simple	04-Feb-2016 13:27:53	 * [new branch] <branch name>
simple	04-Feb-2016 13:27:53	 * [new branch] <branch name>
simple	04-Feb-2016 13:27:53	 * [new branch] <branch name>
simple	04-Feb-2016 13:27:53	 * [new branch] <branch name>
simple	04-Feb-2016 13:27:53	 * [new branch] <branch name>
simple	04-Feb-2016 13:27:53	 * [new branch] <branch name>
simple	04-Feb-2016 13:27:55	 * [new tag]       <tag name>
simple	04-Feb-2016 13:27:55	 * [new tag]       <tag name>
simple	04-Feb-2016 13:27:55	 * [new tag]       <tag name>
simple	04-Feb-2016 13:27:55	 * [new tag]       <tag name>{noformat}

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow the option to disable or suppress these log entries in the build or repository configuration.
fields.summary: Option to Suppress Git New Branch and New Tag Entries in Build Log

fields.description:
There is _MERGE_RESULT_ table which has _FAILURE_REASON_ column with length 4000 symbols. 
For Oracle DB it has length 4000 *bytes*, it causes failures when Bamboo tries to store long message with unicode characters into this column.
fields.summary: Bamboo can't store merge failure on Oracle

fields.description:
I am doing Docker builds in elastic bamboo.  The docker build and run tasks are fine as far as they go, but the problem is when you're using containers you usually need to connect container to container or at least container to a test fixture.  So for example, I have a mongodb running on the build agent, and then I run a container that needs to connect to it.  It needs the box IP to connect to - if you tell the container "localhost" it thinks it's connecting to itself, and with elastic build agents there's no way to predict the box IP (even if using elastic IPs, you're using a set of them and you don't know which one is attached to your instance). This could all be simply accomplished by a system variable that has the box IP.  (For what are I'm sure good security reasons, you can't just put "--env MONGODB_HOST=`hostname -i`" in the arguments in the docker run task). 

Something like bamboo.systemIP or something would do the trick. 

The next layer of improvement would be externalizing the IP/port of containers started by the run task as agent variables so they could talk to each other as well, simply drawn from "docker inspect". It's a very common use case to start one service in container 1 and another in container 2 and tell them to talk to each other, but that requires the ip/port info of the exposed services in question (both are dynamic). 

Workaround:
Always just use script tasks and never use all the more specialized tasks that are supposed to specifically do a thing. This is what we've done, so we just have a script that does a docker run with a hostname -i in it. But that seems like a lot of code you've put into those docker tasks that a lot of people won't be able to use without a little more externalization.
fields.summary: Add system variable with box IP on build instances

fields.description:
The elastic bamboo images have Docker on them but not aufs, which means that when you build docker images it uses the /mnt/docker/devicemapper/data file to the tune of up to 100 GB to build less efficiently.  Building a basic ubuntu docker container with python and tar and such takes about 2.5 GB and fills up the small ephemeral drives that one reasonably uses to launch build agents.

Workarounds:
Yes, I can mount up EBSes instead, I've already done that, adding a 100 GB EBS so that disk space stops being a continual issue on my build agents.
And yes, I can install aufs myself, I've also done that per this gist: https://github.com/docker/docker/issues/9786.

But aufs is the efficient way of building docker images and it's really quite surprising to find a Ubuntu 15.04 image without it (especially one with docker installed) - usually it's just Red Hat nowadays that lacks it. So my suggestion is to install that along with docker on the stock images (most stock 15.04 images I run across have it on already, so it may be just "don't take it off"?).
fields.summary: aufs support for elastic bamboo Ubuntu images

fields.description:
Create plan with large amount of tests, for example : 35000
Run few builds when these tests pass or fail.
When open Summary of this plan Bamboo tries to load all these test cases from DB into memory and display only 50 of them.
At the same time when DB connection is taken by test-related query other queries don't processed - fetching chain details etc. 
Also for each test we fetch last success build number. Not optimal to do it in record by record

On MySQL DB may experience deadlocks 

h3. Workaround
Follow the steps in the following KB article: [Build results summary pages are slow or unresponsive|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Build+results+summary+pages+are+slow+or+unresponsive]
fields.summary: A lot of memory is used when open details of plan with huge amount of tests
Bamboo does not respect the quotes (") in the command line arguments on windows

fields.description:
It would be extremely useful to determine what task is currently being run in the job.  

Potentially, this information can be displayed in the right panel within the build result summary or right justified on the same vertical position as the header of the "Live activity log for <JOB>".

Furthermore, times per task would be excellent information to gather in order to help analyze tasks and optimize build times.

fields.description:
bamboo has limited support for submodules: a git repository can be configured to be checked out recursively. however the submodule commits don't show up in the "Code commits" of a build.

expected behavior:
all changes in the submodule are listed in the "Code commits" of a build
fields.summary: build plan does not list changes in submodules

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The backslash character (\), widely used in regular expressions, cannot be used for capabilities. When entering an expression that contains the character, such as {{windows\d}} (for the string {{windows}} followed by a digit) and clicking *Add*, the following error is returned: This entry cannot contain the character \.

h3. Environment
* Bamboo 5.9.7 or 5.10

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Log into Bamboo
# Click on a plan to edit
# On the top right click *Actions* and select *Configure plan*
# Click on a job
# Click the *Requirements* tab
# From the *Required capability* dropdown select any value
# From the dropdown to the right select *matches*
# In the text field that appears enter {{windows\d}}
# Click *Add*

h3. Expected Results

The capability is added

h3. Actual Results

The following error is displayed: This entry cannot contain the character \.

h3.Workaround
There is no known workaround
fields.summary: Backslash cannot be used in regular expressions for capability requirements

fields.description:
Default artifact packing threshold is set to 10 000 000. In case of an artifact with flat directory structure (single directory with hundreds of files) it will cause Bamboo to OOME.

Workaround: set threshold to a more reasonable value like 100

Possible solutions:
- limit the listing to a defined number of entries
- pagination
fields.summary: OOME when loading enormous artifact listing from S3 bucket

fields.description:
On Bamboo it is possible to filter the Build plans
As wa have a lot of deployment projects the  _<bamboo base url>/deploy/viewAllDeploymentProjects.action_ takes several seconds to load
To make it faster we could use a filter like the build page has
fields.summary: Add ability to filtering on Deployment overview page

fields.description:
Summary
========
Customers would like the ability to pass bamboo variables in to the Docker task. 

This would allow the running of multiple instances of the same image on the same host, which can be extremely useful for testing. Having the ability to also pass in variables for the value of the container ports to be mapped or to set the name of the image to the branch it was built from would be beneficial. 

Reproduction
==========
Using any variables produced by Bamboo in the Container or Port fields will not be correctly validated or expanded. 

Workaround
==========
Workarounds at this time include using a script task to provide the variables to docker. 

See also [Pass In Variables|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/bamboo-docker-plugin/issues/7/pass-in-bamboo-build-variables]
fields.summary: Expand Bamboo variables in Docker task

fields.description: Either always or via a selection, bamboo variables should be able to be exported into the ssh session automatically. We prefer to keep the bash scripts in source control, deploy with artifacts, then invoke as a single line command in the SSH task. However as it stands, we have to export all of the bamboo variable values in the inline script in the SSH task to get them into the environment.
fields.summary: Inject bamboo variables into SSH Tasks
Allow a relased version to reference multiple plans

fields.description:
We have a remote agent that is connecting to a bamboo server instance that is configured using TLS - SNI.  The agent throws an exception indicating that the host name of the self-signed certificate doesn't agree with the actual host name (indicating an SNI) issue.  If the remote jar uses Apache HTTP components less than 4.3.2, it will need to be upgraded.

We were lucky enough to be able to configure the server around the problem, but if that were not possible (and in some environments it will not be), then we would not have been able to  user remote agents.
fields.summary: Bamboo remote agents should support the use of TLS - SNI

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Bamboo server currently does not allow for a load balanced setup. In a load balanced setup users sessions can be distributed between multiple instances of Bamboo servers.
h3. Suggested Solution

In a load balanced setup the Bamboo server instances need a mechanism for synchronisation at the database level and possibly the Bamboo home folders.
fields.summary: Bamboo server load balanced setup

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

The 'Name' drop down on the Dedicate Image page in Bamboo (Bamboo Admin->Image Configurations->Click an image->Dedicate image) will only show a maximum of 25 results. It's possible to filter from there, but it would be handy to be able to show more than 25 results so you can browse through the results more easily.

h3. Suggested Solution

Allow for a 'more' option at the bottom to render more than 25 results.
 
h3. Workaround

Filter by name to find the entry you're looking for
fields.summary: Show more than 25 results for the 'Name' drop down on the Dedicated Image page

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Deployment dashboards suffer performance degradation using MySQL for some users on 5.10.0 and 5.10.1.1. This issue may be most apparent when a user has one or more environments each with a large number of deployments (e.g. 1000+)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Load a large database containing 1000+ deployments per environment using MySQL on Bamboo 5.10.0 / 5.10.1.1
# Open Deployment Dashboard screen


h3. Expected Results
As per improvements made in [BAM-13643|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-13643] the deployment dashboard speed should be greatly improved

h3. Actual Results
Users meeting the criteria described in the summary experience slow load times on the deployment dashboard

h3. Fix
Upgrade to Bamboo 5.10.2 (the latest release as at the time of writing) or later.  Note that slowness has also been reported in 5.10.2: BAM-17322 so MySQL users on 5.9 are advised not to upgrade until that is fixed.
fields.summary: Deployment Dashboards extremely slow in 5.10, particularly against MySQL

fields.description:
Defined a Global Variable named ngc.release.name with no default value set:
!variable_definition.png|thumbnail!
When I go to one of my build plans and select 'Run customised...' I am able to override the variable's value to attribute an actual value to it. If I run the build without attributing a value to it, the variable will be empty. So I have to choose 'Run customised...' because I did not create a default value inside the Global Variables page.
After running the build I go to the 'Medata' tab inside the Build result summary area to confirm that the value I chose is there under the 'Variables' section:
!variable_overwrite.png|thumbnail!
Let's say we also have a Deployment project that's using artifacts produced by this build plan, and that the Release versioning is set like this:
!variable_usage.png|thumbnail!
When I access the Deployment > Environment page and click the '...' button located at the top right corner of the screen and select 'Create release', the field named This version under Define release version should be automatically populated with the value that I used in the last build when I chose 'Run customised...'.

*Workaround*: use one-the-fly version creation from Deployment -> Environment screen:
!deploy_link_1.png|thumbnail!
or
!deploy_link_2.png|thumbnail!
or click on different builds. Version name will be refreshed by ajax to correct naming
fields.summary: Deployment Versioning doesn't use custom plan variables

fields.description:
I created this issue in Bamboo, but it really applies across the various products.

In Support Tools, you can choose to "Create Support Zip" to aid in troubleshooting a support case.  That is a nice and convenient way to gather a wide range of data to submit.

However, all that does is create the zip and then give you the path to the file on the server.  Now the admin has to go access the file system of the server in question and get the file.

Why not simply download the zip file through the browser?  Save that unnecessary last step.

One possible advantage to the way it works now - cleaning up the files.  The user can remove the file from the server once submitted.  However, this could be addressed by a sort of "acknowledge" or other button on the browser screen as the user is downloading the file.  The user would push this button to confirm they have successfully downloaded the file to their local computer, at which point the server can cleanup after itself.
fields.summary: Allow "Create Support Zip" to download directly through browser

fields.description:
We were running Crowd 2.8.0 and Bamboo 5.9.7 on the same server. We were overloading the server and having trouble with Bamboo, so we opted to migrate Bamboo to a new server. We followed the instructions here: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Moving+Bamboo+between+machines.

Everything went fine through step 6 in the instructions. In the setup wizard, we got an error message saying "Import complete" and "import failed". The instructions told us to send you the export file.

Looking at the logs, it looked like the problem was with crowd integration. So, with Bamboo shut down, I modified the crowd.properties file to point to the old server instead of localhost. I went in to Crowd and made sure that the new server IP was in the allowed addresses list. I reset the password for the bamboo application. I removed and re-added the bamboo application.

The Bamboo log shows "connection refused". I successfully tested telnet to the Crowd port from the Bamboo server.

I'm not sure what else to do.

    @Override
    public void doFilter(ServletRequest request, ServletResponse response, FilterChain chain) throws IOException, ServletException {
        HttpServletRequest httpServletRequest = (HttpServletRequest) request;
        request.setAttribute("originalUrl", httpServletRequest.getServletPath());

        String newUrl = parseUrl(httpServletRequest.getServletPath());
        if (newUrl != null) {
            RequestDispatcher dispatcher = request.getRequestDispatcher(newUrl);
            if (dispatcher != null) {
                dispatcher.forward(request, response);
            }
        } else {
            chain.doFilter(request, response);
        }
    }
{code}

fields.description:
When Bamboo automatically creates a link between a JIRA issue and a Bamboo branch, it constantly shows one person as the person who created the link in the JIRA activity stream of the issue. However, this is done automatically so the user is incorrect.

Why does it pick a certain user in the activity stream? And could we assign it to the Bamboo user?

Screenshot attached


Thanks in advance!
fields.summary: Bamboo-JIRA automatically created link shows up under wrong user in JIRA activity stream

fields.description:
Install bamboo-agent using the following command:
{{java -Dbamboo.home=/opt/bamboo-agent -jar atlassian-bamboo-agent-installer-5.10.0.jar https://<PUT_YOUR_SERVER_NAME_HERE>/agentServer/ install}}

running it using the supplied bamboo-agent.sh results in the exception found in the attached log file.
The agent itself does thus not start up correctly but the wrapper keeps trying to run it, causing the agent to try to register with bamboo indefinitely.

If you just rename the folder to some other name e.g. /opt/bambooagent it runs as expected.
fields.summary: Agent startup fails if bamboo.home set to /opt/bamboo-agent

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Setting {{http.proxyUser}} and {{http.proxyPassword}} breaks forward proxy configuration

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Use the following configuration in {{catalina.properties}}, {{setenv.sh}} or the Windows Service.
{noformat:borderStyle=dashed}
#web proxy settings
http.proxyHost=localhost
http.proxyPort=8888
http.nonProxyHosts=localhost
http.proxyUser=admin
http.proxyPassword=admin
{noformat}
(i) Does not need to be a valid proxy server as we are testing against the nonProxyHosts
(i) This problem also occurs if the proxy configuration is set in Bamboo's {{setenv.sh}} rather than in {{catalina.properties}}
# Start Bamboo
# Start Stash on the same server
# Attempt to create application link to the Stash server using the _localhost_ address

h3. Expected Results
The link should be created despite the invalid proxy configuration as {{localhost}} is whitelisted in {{http.nonProxyHost}}

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-bamboo.log file:
{noformat}
2016-01-28 21:26:05,565 INFO [http-nio-8085-exec-22] [AccessLogFilter] admin GET http://10.60.3.18:8085/bamboo/rest/applinks/3.0/manifest.json?_=1453987487624 348848kb
2016-01-28 21:26:05,578 ERROR [http-nio-8085-exec-21] [CreateApplicationLinkUIResource] Exception thrown while retrieving manifest
com.google.common.util.concurrent.UncheckedExecutionException: java.lang.IllegalStateException: org.apache.http.auth.MalformedChallengeException: Authentication challenge is empty
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$Segment.get(LocalCache.java:2203)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache.get(LocalCache.java:3937)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache.getOrLoad(LocalCache.java:3941)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$LocalLoadingCache.get(LocalCache.java:4824)
{noformat}

h3. Notes
Removing the the username and password field, despite using an invalid proxy ip and port, works as localhost is whitelisted as nonProxyHosts

h3. Workaround
Since the problem only affects configurations in which a proxy is used that requires credentials to be provided, a potential workaround is to change the configuration of the proxy server such that it allows connections from the IP address of the machine that Bamboo is running on without requiring credentials.
fields.summary: http.nonProxyHost is ignored if proxy authentication is configured

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When importing a Bamboo instance that contains build results which have labels, the import fails with unique constraint violation errors. 


h3. Environment
* Bamboo 5.10

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Use Bamboo 5.10 and create a plan and run it once
# On the Build result screen add a label (it can be whatever you like)
# Export the Bamboo instance using the Export functionality
# Create a new Bamboo instance and during the setup wizard choose to import an existing instance
# Point to the export zip file generated by step 3 and start the import

h3. Expected Results

The import completes successfully.

h3. Actual Results

An error is displayed on the screen saying the import has failed. A corresponding exception is thrown in the Bamboo log.

The specific error thrown depends on the backend database being used.

fields.summary: Unique key constraint violations occur when importing Bamboo instance that contains build results with labels

fields.description:
Prior to Bamboo 5.10, Bamboo displays information about the database it is connected in the logs to such as:
{noformat:borderStyle=dashed}
2016-01-21 18:11:41,834 INFO [performSetupDatabaseConnectionBackgroundThread] [SettingsFactory] Database ->
       name : MySQL
    version : 5.6.27
      major : 5
      minor : 6
2016-01-21 18:11:41,834 INFO [performSetupDatabaseConnectionBackgroundThread] [SettingsFactory] Driver ->
       name : MySQL Connector Java
    version : mysql-connector-java-5.1.36 ( Revision: 4fc1f969f740409a4e03750316df2c0e429f3dc8 )
      major : 5
      minor : 1
{noformat}

In Bamboo 5.10, this information is no longer available. This information is vital for support in the troubleshooting process.
fields.summary: Include database information in startup logs
